Its very difficult to incorporate old business with new business. People go to an app or website, see a bunch of listings, and pick one to buy. Only ways you can really incorporate the human aspect is in your descriptions where you can paint a story on why they should buy, or customer service. Customer service is almost unheard of with modern business, but I think its key to really stand out. The difficulty is in the scale. Old business was more local while new business is global. You could receive millions of questions and its just impossible to answer them all

Its only impossible when you view customer service as an afterthought. Outsourcing this relationship to a call center in Asia is a like drinking poison when youre sick to hopefully make you better. Relationships at scale is possible when you effectively communicate that as the most important part to your team. Thanks for the comment, I think youre right on the local vs global part. And also I agree certain things should be automated, but then you should use all the time youve saved on the getting a customer to transact, and use it to develop a relationship. Its essentially applying paretos law of 80/20 to relationships in business.

Hey, random question are you into sales or marketing ? I am currently 19 getting ready to finish my first year In college as a marketing major, but I wanna get into sales and just can‚Äôt seem to get a grasp of where to start and what is a good entry level sales job. Great video BTW

Apply for a distributer or setter role, which are always in abundance. There are many entry sales roles, in fact most sales companies force each person to start at the bottom so they can teach their own system of selling. Go start selling telecom products or financial products as there are always jobs for those. I also think it is better to start door-to-door as well as it builds grit faster vs doing solely calls. Another advantage for door-to-door is that, if youre good at it, it is much easier to sell and close vs soley outbound phone.

@Dominique Wilson just from as long as I remember i wanted to be a ‚Äúsalesman‚Äù I think I‚Äôm attracted to being in control of the income. But I‚Äôve been applying for internships just have not really found myself with any success because I have no experience in sales , only work experience I truly have is being a valet and having excellent customer service

I got an internship at a sales training company for about 3 months. Basically I just made about 50 cold calls per day and made appointments for the closers. That was a great entry level position. Wow, I was going to say that a bakers dozen was for product control, but I googled it and I was WAY off. I find it concerning that this video is promoting the idea that success in business is all about networking and building close relationships, and that old business principles are still the most valuable. While it may be true that these factors play a role in achieving success, its important to acknowledge that the business landscape has changed dramatically in recent years due to the internet and technology. The rise of data-driven businesses and the emphasis on customer experience have upended many traditional business models, and its no longer enough to rely solely on relationships and old-school tactics. Additionally, the suggestion that people are the key to success in business oversimplifies the complex dynamics of the modern workplace and ignores the role of systemic issues like discrimination and inequality. While learning from experienced individuals can certainly provide valuable information, we also need to be open to new ideas and approaches that challenge traditional ways of thinking. Overall, I think this video perpetuates a narrow and outdated view of business success, and we need to be more inclusive and forward-thinking in our approach to entrepreneurship.

@Peter MacDonald I appreciate your perspective on the importance of treating customers, employees, partners, and competitors as people rather than just means to an end. However, I think its important to recognize that data can actually be a tool for promoting equity and combating discrimination. Data can reveal patterns of bias and inequality in hiring, promotions, and pay, and can help organizations make more informed decisions to create more equitable and inclusive workplaces. Of course, data alone cannot solve societal issues like racism and sexism, but it can be a powerful tool when used in conjunction with a people-focused approach. Ultimately, the key is to strike a balance between data-driven decision making and a human-centered approach to business. Great video!

I think what you‚Äôve said is totally legitimate and the majority of companies starting today take your approach. With that said, my video is about not throwing out something just because we have something new, innovation doesn‚Äôt = better, unless it actually is better. But my video is addressing a subset of the business world that has abandoned the notion that business is about people and not only about profit. I think when we walk away from that principle business becomes a very dangerous place. Wouldn‚Äôt you agree that when we stop seeing customers, employees, partners, and competitors as people is when we have the most issues with racism, sexism, or discrimination? You‚Äôre not wrong to think the way you do, I would just challenge the idea that data is going to be the salvation to societal issues like this.
